request_pathways.name: Patient Request to Access/Disclose a Designated Record Set
Authorization to Use, Disclose & Release Protected Health Information (general ROI)
Mail to PO Box 4950, Portland, OR 97208

forms.document_type: ROI authorization form (general, third-party and patient access)
Patient access request form (older OR/MT version, superseded)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Providence offers a dedicated patient access form (form-2) specifically for patients requesting their own records, with 'Myself' as the default disclosure option, separate from a general ROI authorization form.

red_flags: Physician approval/denial gate in form-2's internal workflow may create unreasonable barrier to patient access under HIPAA § 164.524
Outdated form-3 remains published alongside current form-2 with stale contact information
bright_spots: Dedicated patient access form separate from general third-party authorization
72 fillable interactive fields — genuinely digital-first PDF design
Five delivery format options including MyChart portal and email
Multilingual language assistance notices in English, Spanish, and Chinese
Multiple submission channels (mail, email, fax) with no in-person requirement

findability.rationale: Level 3: Requires moderate effort — facility-specific search fails; patient must navigate to parent system HIM page and choose among three overlapping forms without clear guidance.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 4: Mostly digital workflow — 72 fillable fields allow complete digital form completion, but wet signature may be required (form-2 is ambiguous); submission available via email and fax.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized with clear section headers and tiered record type options, but minor issues — HIPAA jargon in title ('Designated Record Set'), intimidating invalidation warning, and vague fee language.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 4: Patient access is clearly accommodated with a dedicated form defaulting to 'Myself' as first disclosure option, though the general authorization form is more search-visible and multiple overlapping forms create confusion.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Some requirements that may go beyond legal limits — physician approval gate on patient access, vague fee disclosure without HIPAA cost-based limits, and no response time commitment.

overall.summary: Providence St. Vincent, via its parent system, provides an above-average patient access experience with a dedicated fillable form and multiple submission/delivery options, held back by moderate findability challenges, form proliferation, and a potentially problematic physician approval gate.
